REVIEW TEXT: Each episode of The White Lotus surfaces a different fan-favorite character or performance. But it’s the absurdity of the luxury resort itself that makes the show work.
Moving to a deluxe cliff-side hotel in Taormina, Sicily. but once again revolving around a set of decadent, rich discontents. Mike White's anthology series is opulent, indulgent and compelling.
Season two is tiresome enough that the thought of going through the same formula yet again sounds exceedingly dull.

Mike White’s second series of The White Lotus, which has relocated for its second season from an upscale Hawaiian resort to the fleshpots of Sicily, is still a worthwhile watch, but it’s hard not to wonder where that special savour has gone this time.

As it proved the first time around with such potency, this series is exceptional at letting the supposedly straightforward and idyllic blister like a sunbather catching some rays — and at peeling away layers of ostensible ecstasy in a seeming utopia.
The plotting is almost as fabulous as the scenery, and the witty, ferocious dialogue suggests another round of devious and delicious satire. I am so in.
The White Lotus, while still a pleasure to watch from a schadenfreude standpoint, feels significantly defanged the second time around.
The airless sociological fatalism of Season 1... gives way to a more mature drama, as well as a deeper exploration of how the characters’ class concerns converge with gendered angst.
In some ways, it's a less frustrating experience than the first series. In others, it’s not as punchy.
Fans of the first iteration of Mike White’s “Lifestyles of the Rich and Awful” should recalibrate their expectations a bit.
Creator/writer/director Mike White has effortlessly captured lightning in a bottle for a second time.
The show is more than the sum of its parts, and it is so well written and structured that you will be anxious for each new episode to begin.
Even as it skewers these people, the show is too in love with the idea of being rich to really consider the rot at its core.
Instantly proves to be a worthy follow-up to its excellent predecessor.

The writing is exquisite. White’s dialogue reminds us at every turn that hotels are stage sets: staff and guests alike are always acting until they arrive backstage, at which point their masks slip and crash to the floor.
[Tanya] embodies the show’s essence: that being filthy rich doesn’t make you happy. Indeed, it can make you wretchedly miserable. Enjoy the schadenfreude.
... Just as compelling as the first, with a new set of characters to that viewers will love to loathe.
You may not want to be in the same room with the people you're watching, but the sights alone provided a level of escapism like nothing else on TV.

For the most part, the pivot from observing class and racial politics to sexual politics works in The White Lotus’s favor. Season Two is as juicy as Season One, but it’s not as caustic in its approach.
While overall less frenetic than Season One, White knows how to make watching the imploding the lives of the rich, and their collateral damage, both horrific and delicious.
